title: How to Upgrade Your Hard Drive on the Playstation 4

steps.headline: Remove the front panel.
steps.description: Remove the shiny, polished panel on the top of your PlayStation 4 console. Apply gentle downward pressure to this panel with both hands and slide it away from the center line of the console, until it clicks out of place.

steps.headline: Locate the screw that attaches the console to the bay.
steps.description: This is a round, Phillips head screw with the shapes of the PlayStation logo engraved on it.

steps.headline: Remove the screw.
steps.description: Remove this screw and set it aside. Notice the other Torx screws sprinkled around the hard drive bay, but do not mess with them

steps.headline: Remove the drive.
steps.description: Pull the existing drive out of the bay. Remove any Phillips head screws attaching the old drive to the enclosure before setting it aside.

steps.headline: Remove the old drive from the enclosure.
steps.description: There will be more screws keep the hard drive in the enclosure. Remove them to replace the hard drive.

steps.headline: Insert the new drive.
steps.description: Attach your new drive to the enclosure with the same screws you just removed. The PS4 will support any SATAII drive of no greater thickness than 9.5mm with at least a 160GB capacity. However, it makes the most sense to replace the drive with one that is larger and/or faster than the factory drive.

steps.headline: Reinsert the drive.
steps.description: Slide the enclosed drive into the bay on the side of your console. Ensure that the screw holes on the enclosure and the hard drive bay are aligned

steps.headline: Reinsert the main screw.
steps.description: Insert the large, rounded Phillips head screw from step 2 into the aligned holes and screw it in tightly.

steps.headline: Replace the panel.
steps.description: Replace the shiny black panel to the top of the console. Lay the panel over the exposed hardware so that it is just a couple of inches from the seam, and slide it towards the seam until it clicks back into place.

steps.headline: Install the firmware.
steps.description: Be aware that in order for your new hard drive to work with the PS4, you must install the firmware. Since your system cannot connect to the internet without it, the best method for doing this is via a USB memory stick.
